Description: Architectural design: An interior with flights of stairs, columns, statues and an arch Pen and brown ink, grey wash, heightened with white
Curator's comments: Probably dating from the 1760s, this drawing reflects Challe's interest in the architecture of ancient Greece, Rome and Egypt. His interest developed during his time at the French Academy in Rome, as the winner of the 1741 Prix de Rome, during which time he visited the excavations at Pompeii and Herculaneum. At the same time, he became aware of the etchings of Piranesi, whose influence is also visible here. After his return to Paris, Challe continued to follow the career of the Roman architect, antiquarian and draughtsman, translating his works for a projected but never published French edition.
Acquisition notes: Acquired by Sven Gahlin in 1995 from an anonymous sale at Christie's, London, 3 April 1995, lot 105. This item has an uncertain or incomplete provenance for the years 1933-45. The British Museum welcomes information and assistance in the investigation and clarification of the provenance of all works during that era.
